There is a new nationalism that is sweeping Europe. You want to abolish the nation states, in your case, Mr Schulz, perhaps because you are ashamed of your past. And you now want this flag and a new anthem to replace nation states and you do not care how you get there. If you have to crush national democracy, if you have to oppose popular referendums, you just sweep this aside and say that it is populism.

But it is not, it is democracy. What is sweeping northern Europe now, starting off in April with that amazing result in the Finnish general election, is a new democratic revolution. It is not anti-European. It wants a Europe of trade; it wants a Europe of cooperation; it wants a Europe where we can do student exchanges and we can work in each others’ capital cities; it wants those things. But it does not want this European Union model. Frankly, you are all now yesterday’s men.

a.text: (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 149(8))

intervention.name: Andrew DUFF
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: Mr President, I would like to ask Mr Farage what his answer is for little Britain to the challenges of globalisation.

intervention.name: Nigel FARAGE
intervention.p: Mr President, this point is often made, namely that a country like Britain is only 62 million people and are we not better off being part of a big European club so that we can have more of a voice on the world stage? Funny that, is it not? Here is Britain, the world’s fifth largest trading nation, which is now prohibited from going into World Trade Organisation talks because all of that is done, on our behalf, by an unelected European Commissioner.

Mr Duff, the answer actually is that an independent Britain that trades and cooperates with her European neighbours in an age of globalisation would be able to forge her own trade relationships across the world. It would make sense for a country like ours to start off with the English-speaking world, which shares common law – our own kith and kin in the Commonwealth who we turned our backs on so shamefully.

intervention.name: Laurence J.A.J. STASSEN
intervention.p: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let us face it, the European Union is bankrupt already. This is slowly dragging the Netherlands into a sinking morass. The EEC was adamant that countries like Greece should adopt the euro despite the enormous risks which it was aware of beforehand. As a result of that decision, we are now dealing with a crisis of unparalleled proportions. Meanwhile, the Dutch citizens are being asked to foot the bill.

The Europhiles, who have created these problems, now even want to go a step further. President Barroso, for example, is now openly advocating the introduction of Eurobonds. That is an absurd idea, Mr Barroso. The euro crisis was caused by the southern euro area countries being allowed to borrow money too easily. The last thing we need now are Eurobonds because they will make it even easier for Member States to run into debt. That is the recipe for another crisis.

Who do you think you are actually representing, Mr Barroso? Surely, you realise that Member States such as the Netherlands fiercely oppose these Eurobonds. Why are you not supporting the countries which are still keeping the European Union going? Mr President, the situation is clear as far as we are concerned: Mr Barroso has sided with the euro sinners. In the meantime, Member States, such as the Netherlands, whose household budgets are in order, are being squeezed out like a lemon in order to foot the bill for fraudulent Greece, for example. Mr Barroso, as far as my party, the Dutch Party for Freedom (PVV), is concerned, you might as well clear your desk and go and look for another job. The President of the Commission ought to protect the interests of all Member States. The PVV is of the opinion that you are not capable of that.

intervention.name: Mikołaj Dowgielewicz
intervention.role: President-in-Office of the Council
intervention.p: Mr President, President Barroso, Commissioner, honourable Members, first of all let me thank you, Mr President, for the opportunity to speak on behalf of the Council in this crucial debate. I would like to thank President Barroso for his remarks, and I especially want to emphasise what he said about the need to restore growth in the European Union. This has been reflected in a number of interventions today. The growth agenda is also at the very heart of the Polish Presidency programme, where we are working very closely with the Commission ahead of the October European Council.

Here let me mention two elements: first of all, the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy. It is the EU institutions and the Member States working together in the framework of EU 2020 which will ensure that we emerge stronger from the crisis. Second, the negotiations on the multi-annual financial framework, which we started this autumn. There are, of course, very different opinions on the MFF to be reconciled. Everybody refers to the economic climate that underpins those discussions. In any case we will have to find compromises, and for the Council Presidency there are two elements which are absolutely crucial in those discussions.

First of all, we must have a comprehensive, profound debate on the basis of the proposal from the Commission. Secondly we must find consensus on the idea that the money should be spent on supporting Europe in its search for stable and balanced growth.

Mr President, let me use this opportunity briefly to say that we are looking forward to the very important vote today in Parliament: a very important vote for economic and monetary union and a very important vote for the European Union. This vote on the ‘six pack’ is a milestone on our way out of the debt crisis and towards more fiscal and economic transparency and discipline. This will also mean more power for the Commission, and I am happy that we have found support for these proposals in the Council.

I also want to acknowledge in this process the role that Parliament has played in making sure that the package is coherent and ambitious and the fact that you have shown flexibility and responsibility.

Another example, from the last 48 hours: correlation tables, where we actually enhance the role of the Commission as the guardian of the Treaties. This is also a way of showing that we are transparent in the implementation of European legislation and that the Union works.

Finally, another example from the last twelve hours: a compromise in the trialogue on the external financial instruments. The reason why I mention those three – the six pack, correlation tables and the external financial instruments – is very simple. The message is: the Community method works. The sceptics can be proved wrong, and I address this to Mr Zahradil in particular, because I think people from your party in the Czech Republic and Poland do not read the facts, they just live in a dream that the European Union will crumble. I think you will be proved wrong.

To close, I just want to say that, concerning economic and monetary union, Schengen, foreign and security policy, the single market, energy and all the issues that President Barroso raised today, you can count on an approach by the Presidency which will include more Europe, not less Europe; more support for the Community method rather than intergovernmentalism; and finally, support for ever-closer union and not for ever-looser union. That is the only way to rebuild trust.

intervention.name: Mario MAURO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Mr President, President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, many, perhaps all of us, called before this debate for more courage. From today, I believe that we must call you ‘Barroso the Lionheart’.

The economic crisis is also an institutional crisis, and it is right, as you said, that we should relaunch the European project and seek new solutions to the crisis that we are experiencing. Fear is actually the driving force of a populist and nationalist vision, and it is courage that is, by contrast, the value that created Europe and has given it peace and prosperity.

Mind, though, Mr Barroso, although our ideas and your proposals are the antithesis of populism, our voters are often that way inclined. This means that if the reforms that you outlined are not implemented in the course of the next few months, they will paradoxically become the pretext for Eurosceptic criticism. You began this round with three aces, Mr Barroso. Now play the ace of hearts of the ‘Lionheart’, submit your proposals to Parliament and the Council, and together we shall win this hand.

intervention.name: Corien WORTMANN-KOOL
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) - Vice
intervention.p: Mr President, thank you. I would like to congratulate you, President Barroso, on the decisiveness with which you explained here the Community method needed to rescue our single currency.

We will soon be taking a crucial vote on the ‘six pack’, which will see the European Commission set up as an independent authority. It has taken months to get the Council to come this far. However, this Parliament has stood firm. It is now crucial that we in this House come together and vote ‘yes’, because that will allow us to build on this achievement.

We call on you to make sure you see through these ambitious proposals, because we are standing at a crossroads. We could decide today to build further on the Community method for economic governance in Europe and to reform it. The alternative is: chaos on the financial markets and Heads of State or Government having the final say. That too is an option, of course. We in this House will then have to do further work, together with all political groups, on the proposals you have presented today in order to strengthen future governance.

intervention.name: Tanja FAJON
intervention.p: Mr President, President Barroso, you have said that we should be frank. You have made some very important statements and I thank you for this.

We would like more Europe, but we cannot seem to find any more common political will. You made a good point in saying that Europe will have a future if we manage to establish trust, for which we first need stable growth and political will on the part of our leaders.

People are concerned, frightened. We live in a time when many young people no longer see the reason for European integration. They are concerned only with living their lives. You have announced that you will call on companies to offer young people more work opportunities and make use of the European Social Fund. This is not enough. We need tangible action, and young people need hope.

The crisis of trust is just as serious as the economic and financial crisis. Our citizens will never support our actions unless they trust us. Our measures are always accompanied by tardiness and indecision. We are even losing a generation of young people that still believes in Europe. We are also losing countries waiting to join the Union, the countries of the Western Balkans. These countries have a European perspective but, President Barroso, you have not mentioned their future once today.
That is why we must win back the people’s trust. Thank you very much.

intervention.name: Charles GOERENS
intervention.p: Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Barroso that Europe needed this speech. You have rarely been as much in tune with your audience. One more diagnosis? Yes, but coupled with undeniable determination. This is a pleasant contrast to the rather withdrawn role that the Commission has played over recent years.

However, allow me to be somewhat doubtful, to my great regret I must add. Those of our Member States that have, for years, been going all out against the EU are not here today to tell us if they agree with the broad lines of your speech.

One speaker has just said that Robert Schuman and Jean Monnet’s ideas are more than 150 years old. Allow me to point out that, in an attempt to oppose Jean Monnet and Robert Schuman’s ideas, Mr Zahradil, who we are talking about here, has just used ideas more than 150 years old.

intervention.name: Othmar KARAS
intervention.p: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you have made it quite clear today, Mr Barroso, that you are not an honest broker, you are the head of the European government. Your Commission is responsible for economic governance. This is why we are opposed to any duplicate structures. We should now be making an effort to end this cacophony and to turn the President of the Commission into the Chair of the Heads of State or Government of the 17 and Mr Rehn into the Chair of the eurozone, until the Treaty is amended.

Present us with a road map for creating an economic and social union. Make it clear that you need a budget which enables the Commission to act. Thank you for the own resources. Thank you for the transaction tax. More determination, more ambition and more enthusiasm will bring young people on board and give us a positive future.

intervention.name: Paulo RANGEL
intervention.p: Mr President, Dr Barroso, I should naturally like to congratulate you on the additional hope that you have given to all us Members of the European Parliament and, in particular, to the citizens of the European Union whom we represent here. Having said that, I should also like to say that we are now expecting very, very determined action from the Commission alongside the Council, so that this sovereign debt crisis might be resolved in short order.

We know that it is a marathon, but immediate signals are necessary. Therefore, leaving aside the fact that we are all thinking already about amending the Treaties that are the political expression of the entire project that we have brought this far, leaving that aside, something needs to be done now. This package of measures and, perhaps, an agreement; an agreement between all the Member States, along the lines of what we have been calling a ‘shareholders’ agreement’ that goes beyond the Treaties and could put all these ideas into practice, starting now.
Many congratulations on your courage and your determination. I believe we are on the right track and will leave here today with new determination.

intervention.name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Mr President, Mr Daul said, quite rightly in my opinion, that after this crisis nothing is likely to be the same. The debt crisis will probably alter Europe’s status if no solutions to it are found in the future.

Let me give you an example. Until now, Europe has been putting pressure on China to implement human rights and the rule of law. Now it would appear that China is starting to put pressure on Europe to acknowledge, for example, its market economy status. In the future, that might lead China to put pressure on Europe to accept mediocre environmental norms and a low level of consumer protection. That is why it is absolutely important for Europe’s future status in the world to be free of this debt crisis. For that reason, all the efforts that you, Mr Barroso, have proposed are very important and deserve our respect.

intervention.name: Emilie TURUNEN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance - Vice
intervention.p: Mr President, President of the Commission, thank you for your speech. I have to say that it is actually the first time in two years that I believe what you are saying. I think that you made a good speech today. Having said that, however, I would also like to say that we are experiencing a very serious crisis, both in political and in economic terms. We therefore need to put words into action. You need to show us results, and you need to show us concrete proposals. I would like to make a few comments in this regard, because we need something that goes far beyond what we have on the table right now. We need a comprehensive, coordinated crisis plan for Europe, which will ensure stability, sustainability and social justice.

In this connection, we need three things: 1) a resolute assurance to the markets that we are standing shoulder to shoulder with regard to the euro – there must be no more hitches, and you must take the lead here; 2) we cannot use cuts and savings to bring us more growth and employment – we need an investment plan and a jobs plan; 3) the focus needs to be placed on revenue again in Europe. Thank you for your proposal for a financial tax – we have waited a long time for it. Mr Barroso, we must convert what you have said today into concrete action. We need to stop believing that cuts and pretence can save Europe. We must have an overarching, comprehensive crisis strategy, and that is the most important job for you to do over the next few months.

intervention.name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: Mr President, you have made a very good speech, Mr Barroso. What is important now is putting it into practice, in other words, the follow-up, as Mr Verhofstadt has said, and ensuring that something really happens here. I believe that we agree almost unanimously that we need more Europe in order to be able to overcome this crisis. However, we need the right Europe and for us that means that we want a stability union rather than a debt union. We need to include a ‘debt brake’ in the national constitutions. We still need, and here my opinion differs from that of the Chair of my group, different interest rates, because they act as an economic ‘debt brake’. We also need an organised process for national bankruptcy. We need rules which determine what happens when a country becomes unable to pay its debts, so that we can keep it in the eurozone. That is the crucial point. We need a stability pact with teeth and with automatic sanctions. I would like to say one thing. The plan by the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament and the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance to vote against this tougher stability pact here today is a continuation of Gerhard Schröder’s policy of 2003, which aimed to destroy the stability culture of Europe.

intervention.name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
intervention.p: Mr President, this debate on the state of the Union comes at a critical time; as others have already said, it is the worst in the Union’s history.

Therefore, although the state of the Union is not good, I join those who have expressed their conviction that the unrest that can be felt throughout Europe is not a result of what Europe does, and much less what Europe says – which is often applauded in this Chamber – but rather the lack of Europe, what Europe does not do, and the contradiction between what it says and applauds, and what it actually does.

Our governments talk about making difficult decisions. They impose those decisions on the citizens, but they do not impose them on themselves. Are they willing to give up their short-sightedness and short-termism, their strictly local and national interests, in favour of necessary solutions? Are they ready to do what has to be done, rather than doing too little too late, in a fragmented way and in the wrong direction?

Furthermore, I might add that it is not true that in order to do what must be done, it is necessary to reform the Treaties. Absolutely not. I agree with those who believe wholeheartedly that there was a time when we did not have instruments, but we did have determination and will. Now we have the instruments, but we are lacking the will and leadership.

a.text: (The President cut off the speaker)

intervention.name: Jean-Paul GAUZÈS
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Mr President, a few days ago, I told you, in a friendly way, a number of things. You have not missed today’s opportunity.

We heard – at last, I would say – these strong words that are necessary if we want to address the political decision crisis that we are in, for beyond the economic, financial and social crisis that you described, and the confidence crisis, there was and is a political decision crisis.

By asserting today loud and clear the Commission’s role and its constructive proposals – of which some have already been implemented, on financial regulation in particular – and thanks to this Parliament, thanks to what will be voted for later on I hope, and thanks to the joint work that we will once again undertake – like Mr Schulz said earlier on – I think that we can make Europe move forward in the right direction and give you all the support you need, and that, henceforth, you fully deserve.

intervention.name: Marisa MATIAS
intervention.p: Mr President, Dr Barroso, honestly, a year ago you announced Eurobonds here. You repeated yourself today and I suspect that in a year’s time you will repeat yourself again. We could even end up with you introducing yourself to us saying ‘the name’s Bond, Eurobond’.

We all want Eurobonds, Dr Barroso, but the truth, and the problem, is that the secret agent that we currently have, who has secret plans and a licence to kill, is Chancellor Merkel. Today we have found out about the Eureka plan. If you have any information about this plan, Dr Barroso, I should very much like you to give it to us, because we too would like to know about these secret plans to, supposedly, save Europe from crisis.

However, changing subject, I should like to ask you if you have spoken about Palestine, Dr Barroso. We already know that the European Union does not have a common position on Palestine. What I cannot grasp, but would like to understand, is how it is that Europe has a word to say about these peace process negotiations, when the proposed budgetary support for the Palestinian Authority in 2012 represents half the sum implemented in 2010 and a cut of one third in relation to 2011. I should like you to comment on this please.
Finally, Dr Barroso, do not offer internships to the young people whom you mentioned demonstrating in the streets: offer them employment policies. They will thank you and so will we.

intervention.name: Niki TZAVELA
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group - Vice
intervention.p: Mr President, I would like to thank President Barroso for his inspiring Community speech. We in the south started as pigs and are now in a period of being guinea pigs. We do not object to that. If we have to be the guinea pigs for testing and finding out the methodology and the process of having a real coherence and a real unity within the European Union, we accept that, but how long will this experiment last?

As a Greek, I accept all the criticism and admit that we have made mistakes and are still making mistakes, but I will do so within my own Parliament and my country. As a European, the question is: how long will the experiment last? If we are to be the catalyst for having a real Union and for having a structural, institutional coherence we accept it. It is worth it.

intervention.name: Diane DODDS
intervention.p: Mr President, there is a real sense of déjà vu in this House this morning. We have heard the scale of the economic nightmare, we hear the supposed solutions, and yet, Mr Barroso, we have heard you speak in this House on these things with these promises of solutions many times before.

That sense of déjà vu was heightened for me when I heard one Member actually say that, after your speech, you should be called ‘Barroso the Lionheart’. What nonsense. The political class in this House, led by you and the Presidents in this House, should hang their heads in shame. We have a monetary union that has been politically inspired. It is an ideology that is not working and that is costing Europe’s citizens a significant amount of money as they suffer cuts and more and more depression and a greater downturn in economic growth.

intervention.name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
intervention.p_group: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
intervention.p: Mr President, Mr Barroso has said today that the European Commission is the de facto economic government of the Union, and we can infer that it is going to seek formalisation of this state of affairs. Using the crisis as justification, the Union wants not only to recover, but also to move forward, strengthening integration and creating the foundations of a European superstate. However, all the talk about the economic crisis is ignoring the crisis of democracy and the crisis of values. Further possibilities have been announced today concerning amendment of the Treaty of Lisbon, which was adopted against the will of the citizens expressed in referendums held in several EU Member States. Indeed, the process of constructing a European state is being carried on without any reference to the most important values upon which Europe is built, by which I mean Christian values. What is more, we are witnessing an attempt to disown them. It needs to be stated clearly and emphatically that no reform will be successful without a return to the true roots of Europe.

intervention.name: Sylvie GOULARD
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: Mr President, you said lots of very apt things on poverty, on the tax on financial transactions and on Eurobonds, which, thanks to Olli Rehn and a very fruitful cooperation, we are trying to move forward together.

I have one question, Mr Barroso. I am asking it without any bad feeling: why should we believe you today? Why – you who have been seven years at the head of the Commission and two years in the driving seat of the European boat during the crisis – have you waited until today? Do not forget, and I especially have in mind those young people you mentioned, that, if you fail, your responsibility before History will be enormous, and so will ours if we simply sit back and watch the disaster unfold.

intervention.name: Wim van de CAMP
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Barroso very much for his speech, especially for the many specific measures he has mentioned.

As a Dutchman, I am always concerned about the pace of the progress we are making. I have the impression that the financial markets want Europe to speed things up. We have a saying in the Netherlands which goes: ‘There is a difference between being right – and Mr Barroso is, indeed, right – and proving yourself to be right’. We need to prove ourselves right.

We have already spoken about the relationship with the Council this morning, but I would ask Mr Barroso to reflect on the criticism from outside Europe. Mr Greithner was in Poland last week, where he felt it his place to make comments on the pace of reform in Europe. The BRICS countries, too, now want to help Europe. I, personally, find that to be tantamount to an insult to Europe. I would appreciate a response from you.

intervention.name: Tunne KELAM
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Mr President, my country, Estonia, is completing its ninth month in the turbulent eurozone, but I am still clear that the best way to defend the interests of Estonia or France or Portugal is to stand united and to defend first of all the interests of Europe as a whole.

Fingers have today been pointed at the Council. Its will and leadership in acting decisively and convincingly will be crucial to restore trust in the eurozone and the European Union as a whole. Continuing with intergovernmental methods is probably a certain way back to chaos. We now need to head towards an economic union whose speed cannot be dictated by its slowest members.

As for the financial stability facility, it has been tailored to address the crisis in the smaller states. Now the contagion has spread to the big states, and I wonder whether the competences of this authority should now be expanded.

intervention.name: Jean-Pierre AUDY
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Mr President, well done Mr Barroso, you have a balanced and apt view of the seriousness of the situation and of the common solutions that need to be found.

I have listened carefully to the criticisms on the methods. Today, in this House, there are notable absentees: our Heads of State or Government. I have the following dream: that we would have a great political debate on the state of the Union, with the European Commission in its entirety – that is the case – representatives of the people, Heads of State or Government with their representatives, and President Van Rompuy. I would like to ask the heads of the political groups: did we invite Mr Van Rompuy? Did we invite the Heads of State or Government, as well as representatives of the national parliaments?

There is a European Council on 17 October. It will be a momentous political moment. We must put your proposals on the table, Mr Barroso, we must have a big political debate with President van Rompuy, who could prepare this European Council session, at our mini part-session in Brussels on 13 October.

intervention.name: Csaba Sándor TABAJDI
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Mr President, Mr Barroso, I was reminded of the words of a Hungarian poet: ‘We are always late for everything.’ Your speech came late, Mr Barroso. Europe is as much hostage to extortion by financial and banking circles as it is to the indecisiveness and dilly-dallying of the European political elites. Where was the European Commission in August, Mr Barroso? Where was the European Parliament? We can criticise the Heads of State or Government, but at least they broke their holidays. Europe cannot be governed with such an attitude. It is unfortunate that the Members of the Group of the European People’s Party (Christian Democrats) postponed the final vote on the legislative ‘six pack.’ What would have been appropriate in June is no longer enough, it is now insufficient and more is needed. A policy of austerity is not enough, yet all the European right-wing, including the Hungarian right-wing can come up with is austerity. Without economic growth and job creation Europe will never break the shackles of debt.

intervention.name: Maria Eleni KOPPA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Mr President, today we need to decide if the Union is in a better state than it was last year. Unfortunately, the answer is that it is not. Europe, both in the eyes of European citizens and on the international scene, seems to be weaker and more vulnerable in the face of the crisis. The economic debate is marked by indecisiveness, doublespeak and an inability to take bold decisions which, when they are taken, albeit belatedly, are called into question the very next day. On the issue of the area of security and freedom, we have seen unilateral acts which directly call the Schengen Agreement into question. At the level of the common foreign policy, this year has demonstrated once again Europe’s inability to speak with one voice.

Mr President, Greece has undertaken to discharge its obligations in full but, if the Greek people are to stay on the difficult path of sacrifice, the message from Europe must be clear and unequivocal, just as your message was today.

intervention.name: Marielle de SARNEZ
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe - Vice
intervention.p: I would like to say to President Barroso that I appreciated his speech and that he is absolutely going in the right direction, but I would like us to agree that, in the last 18 months, the European institutions have not really been equal to the task of dealing with the crisis – that is my take, at least – and that they have not succeeded, to say the least, in stemming what is, in essence, a crisis of confidence, as well as this debt crisis and the crisis of the euro area. Today, the result is that our European Union is weakened. So, is a shake-up possible? You said that it is. Well, I wish you were right.

There are several conditions for this: firstly, we need to press all the political players and all the European institutions to come together. Secondly, we need to reaffirm loud and clear the principles that have made Europe, namely solidarity and the community spirit. Thirdly, we need to say that a single country leaving the euro area is not a possibility. You said so and that is good. Fourthly, we need to put on the table a coherent comprehensive package. Mr Verhofstadt talked about this in detail, so I will not go over it again. Finally, we need to make progress towards real economic governance, but we will also have to move towards real political governance. Never have there been so many responsibilities.

a.text: (The President cut off the speaker)

intervention.name: Rui TAVARES
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: Mr President, Dr Barroso, I told you a year ago that you had not woken up to the crisis. Now the crisis is here, it has made itself felt very clearly and it has woken everyone up. My fear is that it will be too little too late.
Europe needs three things. Firstly, it needs its single currency to issue debt in its name, like any currency in the real world: it cannot continue with 17 different debts.
Secondly, it needs this debt to be used on a plan for economic recovery, for jobs, for public investment, and for the construction of infrastructure. We agree on that.

It needs a third thing. It needs the political legitimacy to use this debt and to make this economic recovery plan. That is a thing that the President of the Commission can guarantee, by taking steps to ensure that the next President of the Commission is the man or woman chosen by the 500 million citizens in the 2014 elections.

The purpose of this would be that, in the end, when there are good ideas on the table, they cannot be killed off by the leaders of Paris or Berlin at a summit next door to a casino, and that the voice of the 500 million would make itself heard so that we could have a European Union with genuine solidarity; not the type of solidarity that we have now, which, I must confess, scares me a little more each time I hear it mentioned.

intervention.name: Miloslav RANSDORF
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: Mr President, following the events of 1953 in Berlin, when the politburo of the Socialist Unity Party of Germany issued the statement that the people had forfeited the confidence of the politburo, Bertolt Brecht recommended that the politburo elect another people who would not forfeit its confidence. I got the impression from the speech of President Barroso and others that the European states, the European nations, had forfeited the confidence of the Commission. I would therefore like to recommend that President Barroso elects another European people, who will not forfeit his confidence.

intervention.name: Jaroslav PAŠKA
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group - Vice
intervention.p: Mr President, in spite of the huge effort the Council, the Commission and the European Parliament have invested in stabilising the Europeam monetary system, we cannot say that this has been a great success. I do not think that calling each other names and trying to pin the blame for the bad situation on the Council or national governments is particularly fair.

Surely you realise that you are asking the new Member States to take on additional obligations in the name of their citizens to stabilise the insolvent countries in a situation where, for example, the average income in Slovakia is under EUR 400, even though this is almost one-quarter of the average wage in troubled Greece, while the average salary is about EUR 800, which is also several times lower than in the countries that are expecting to be bailed out.

If you are such a gentleman, Mr President, please try to stand up before Slovakia’s citizens and tell them that they have to save even more and get even more deeply into debt only to maintain the much higher incomes in the wealthier, insolvent countries. I do not think that you can really appeal to people’s sense of solidarity in this case …

a.text: (The President cut off the speaker)

intervention.name: Jo LEINEN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Mr President, Mr Barroso, you have called for a renaissance of the European idea. I believe that we agree that the European idea is good, but it requires a new foundation and a new profile to explain why we need Europe and also more Europe in the 21st century. As the Chair of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, one thing is clear to me. Europe must become a stability union from an environmental perspective and not just from a financial perspective.

Young people understand above all that with 9 billion of us living on the planet by the middle part of the century, we will be fighting for energy, raw materials and food. Therefore, let us establish a European pact for environmental stability which includes energy efficiency, the efficient use of resources and sustainability. We have started to do this and it must not be allowed to get lost or be given a lower priority during the crisis. These problems will not go away. They will remain and they may even become more pronounced. Please encourage the whole of the Commission to make progress with the environmental profile of the EU. We will have the young people of Europe behind us.

intervention.name: Karin KADENBACH
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Mr President, Mr Barroso, you have spoken today of a renaissance and I am joining Mr Leinen in referring to this. Renaissance means rebirth. If we are to give birth to something again, we should be aware of what sort of environment the new project is being born into. We only have complete agreement about the European project in one area and that is the European peace project. The policymaking which is currently going on will put this project and this trust at risk.

Today we have frequently heard the criticism that the flame of Europe is obviously only really burning in this Chamber and that a great deal of child abandonment is taking place, when we look at the Council and the individual Member States. This means that it will be our joint task – the Members of Parliament, your task as President and, most importantly, the task of the Council Presidency – to help to ensure that this renaissance takes place in an environment where we have the trust of the people. We will not have this trust if we take the European Union not only in the direction of being an economic and monetary union, but also in the direction of a social union. I believe that this is also missing in the ‘six pack’. It provides no guarantee that the economy will be sustainable or that there will be opportunities for the future. We will only have a future in Europe, if the people come with us into the future.

intervention.name: Antonio CANCIAN
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Mr President, Mr Barroso, ladies and gentlemen, today, Mr Barroso, you sounded full of vim and vigour, and that gives us hope for the immediate future.

The crisis calls for immediate choices and timescales that we should probably not have chosen in normal circumstances. I cannot nor do I wish to imagine the scenario that would unfold if Europe and the euro were to fail. Therefore the choices turn on three issues: on reforms to the way that things work, a plan to emerge from the crisis and attention to timing. I shall refer solely to the plan for a solution to the crisis, which is growth, and which must be achieved. Here we have a great game, which you mentioned in connection with project bonds, relating to this Marshall plan, which we can now call a modern ‘Barroso plan’, concerning the EUR 1.6 trillion that are going into the construction of this great infrastructure plan.
To make those of us who believe like me and like so many in this House once more proud of this Europe: that is the goal we must achieve right away. Pay heed to the urgency, President Barroso.

intervention.name: Íñigo MÉNDEZ DE VIGO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Mr President, President of the Commission, today was an important day, and Mr Barroso’s speech was an important one. I think you have achieved a good result, because you have established the three Cs: courage, credibility and confidence.

It has been said here that the Community method is antiquated. However, the Community method has brought us many years of peace and prosperity. The Commission plays a vital role in that method; indeed, it lies at the very heart of it.
It is therefore very significant that today, at this time of crisis and confusion when our people are asking for guidance, the President of the European Commission has made such a committed speech.
Mr Barroso, you can count on Parliament’s political support when those commitments are turned into initiatives. I offer you my congratulations.

intervention.name: Edite ESTRELA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Mr President, I should like to begin by congratulating you on your strong speech, Dr Barroso, and on the message of determination that you have brought before us, for which you received deserved applause.

You spoke of a Europe of citizens. Now the citizens are asking, how we have managed to reach this crisis, and so many sacrifices, when Europe has 7% of the world’s population and 22% of its gross domestic product.

However, the big question is this: what is our escape route? You know, Dr Barroso, that the citizens are sick of words: what they want is action. One of the actions that should already have been taken is putting a stop to tax havens. During the French presidential elections, President Sarkozy talked about putting a stop to tax havens, but nothing has been done as yet.

In addition, we also need to move ahead with fiscal harmonisation, because no single currency can survive without fiscal harmonisation. I believe it is important to stress this, and that austerity and responsibility should be in harmony with solidarity.

intervention.name: Sophie AUCONIE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Mr President, Mr Barroso, I would like to talk to you more specifically about the public service sector, to tell you that it is vital for the European Union’s economy. May I remind you that it represents 26% of GDP and a third of all jobs in the European Union.

What is the Commission doing in this regard? On Michel Barnier’s initiative, it published last April the Single Market Act – you mentioned it – which is aimed at boosting growth within the internal market. I welcome this initiative. For his part, Commissioner Almunia published only a few days ago a reform on state aid rules that apply to economic services of general interest. His ambition to simplify and clarify is supported by our Parliament.

Beyond these two initiatives, Mr Barroso, I believe the Commission should be much more ambitious still. At the start of this parliamentary term, you committed yourself to proposing a communication on this matter to Parliament before the end of 2011. However, there is no sign of that yet.
Mr Barroso, should we not promote this sector now more than ever? This is important in the period we are going through.

intervention.name: Sir Graham WATSON
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: Mr President, I am sure the House will wish Mr Barroso luck in aligning the individual interests of Member States with the collective interest of the Union. We welcome his proposal for stability bonds to lay the basis for future growth.

Many of us understand that Germany has no wish to add to its public debt of EUR 2 000 billion the underwriting of some EUR 3 200 billion issued by the weaker countries of the Union, but does he foresee for the future a common budgetary programme for the eurozone, so that common bonds might be issued for future borrowing? Will he seek to extend the mandate of the European Central Bank, perhaps to add the pursuit of sustainable growth to the goal of price stability?

intervention.name: Alfreds RUBIKS
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: Mr President, when I sit in this chamber, Mr Barroso, and listen to your speeches, I feel like clapping, but when I go back to my electors in Latvia and listen to what they say to me, I feel like weeping. Latvia is dying out. Latvia has become one of the poorest countries in the European Union. In addition to everything you have listed, I should like to add a further point – we must take care that our actions agree with our words. We speak a good deal about solidarity, about fairness and about cohesion, but how should a Latvian farmer understand the word ‘cohesion’ if you are planning to pay only 52% of the average [rate] per hectare in the European Union to a Latvian farmer in 2020?

intervention.name: Angelika WERTHMANN
intervention.p: Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Barroso that none of us actually knows the outcome of the current Greek crisis, although everyone is worried about the future of the euro and some even about the Union. To get out of this crisis we have to help and support Europe’s people first. It is of utmost importance to invest in education to boost the job market and to reduce the unemployment rate in Europe, especially among young people. Concerning the EU’s finances, we have to first ask the respective agents to take their responsibility. One thing has to be clearly understood, namely that Member States’ overspending must end since the consequences are taken out on our taxpayers. Finally, I would like to thank him very much for today’s speech but ask him to go ahead and do the work now.

intervention.name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: Mr President, Europe is in a debt crisis, although, in fact, there is of course money in Europe. The issue is mainly about a crisis of confidence – a crisis of credibility. Commission President, you proposed amending the Treaties. This crisis will not be resolved with new treaties, but through compliance with existing ones – existing commitments. The Member States have to bring their economies into balance and cut debt.

I fear that you, Commission President, will be leading the EU out of an economic crisis into a treaty crisis. The EU cannot afford new crises now: this has to be dealt with in a controlled manner, in compliance with the Treaties. I do not support Eurobonds either. They will only lead to new crises by allowing Member States to continue borrowing irresponsibly, both now and in the future.

intervention.name: Andrew DUFF
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: Mr President, it is great that we have to install a federal economic government and that this has been recognised by the Commission and acclaimed by Parliament, but I think that also poses problems about the popular legitimacy of this House. Would you agree with me that it is essential also to develop the European political parties to connect the citizen with the strengthened form, style and force of a government that we are going to have?

intervention.name: Pervenche BERÈS
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Mr President, Mr Barroso, you do, after all, sometimes listen to the socialists, since you are going to propose a tax on financial transactions and on Eurobonds. So please listen to us for a bit longer and mobilise your Commission so that the Community power of initiative is used to fight effectively against tax evasion, rather than leaving each of the Member States to negotiate bilateral agreements with Switzerland.

Then, listen to us on the social issue too because, you must admit, this morning you were a little brief. What did you say about an initiative in the area of company restructurings? We are waiting for strong proposals in many areas where, evidently, you are struggling to convince the Member States. The fact is, that is your mission and your role.

Furthermore, you said this morning that you had asked the Council for the outstanding EUR 400 million so that food banks can do their work this year in the economic disaster that we are going through.

Take up your pilgrim’s staff, do your work so you can convince one Head of State after the other. You have an essential task to accomplish, and if you fail, those who live in poverty will be the victims of Europe, and that, we cannot accept.

intervention.name: Krisztina MORVAI
intervention.p: Mr President, this morning’s session reminded me very much of the congresses of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union in its dynamics, especially as there is one man speaking from the podium and about 90% of those who watch him in front of their television sets understand that what the man says has nothing whatsoever to do with reality and with their experiences, yet their representatives applaud enthusiastically. Why? Because there is a huge gap between the representatives and those whom they are supposed to represent. That is something that should immediately be changed.

Another similarity is that those who want fundamentally to protest and change the system have to face police brutality, as we had to in Hungary between 2006 and 2010. For example, the trade union leader Judit Szima has now been under house arrest for several months, and György Budaházy and Endre Szász, who are opposition leaders who tried to fundamentally alter the system, have been in prison for three years now.

intervention.name: Philippe LAMBERTS
intervention.p: Mr President, Mr Barroso, you have managed to find a tone that the indignados from Puerta del Sol would not have disowned when it comes to the banking sector.

We would have liked to have seen the same indignation when, on 21 July, you accepted the conditions that the banks dictated to you for the second Greek rescue package. We would have liked to have seen the same indignation when you adopted new rules for banks. The fact is, the CRD IV is merely a pale imitation of Basel III. When are you going to impose the separation between casino banks and the banks that genuinely finance the economy?

Finally, I would like to go back to the two figures you quoted on the financial transaction tax. You say that European citizens have committed up to EUR 4 600 billion and you proudly announce that the financial transaction tax could bring in EUR 50 billion per year. I do not see that as a reason to be elated. In any case, I do not see in that the sign of a genuine indignation towards those who are tearing Europe apart.

intervention.name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Mr President, concerns over the stability of the euro and the state of the Union in general are unfortunately here to stay. Although the Commission, the Council and the ECB took considerable steps to calm the international markets, we have yet to see a satisfactory solution to the financial crisis and Greece’s bankruptcy. I agree with you that it could give reason for hope that the EU already took a historic leap once in the past fifty years, similar to the one required to solve the current situation. We are now in a similar historic situation, as today we will be voting about the legislative ‘six pack’ that redefines the foundations of economic governance and also contains the key to our common economic success; however, all of this is has no meaning if the single currency is not sufficiently stable. The founding fathers, too, would probably be rather taken aback if more than fifty years after the founding of the Community they had to thank the BRICS countries, of all, for leading the euro area out of the crisis. Mr President, I respectfully ask you to submit your proposal as soon as possible.

intervention.name: Elmar BROK
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Mr President, I would like to thank you for your clear statement on the Community method, Mr Barroso. We should remember that when the Stability and Growth Pact was breached and when the Schengen Agreement was breached by countries such as Denmark, one thing became clear: it is the Member States which are breaking the rules via the Council. If we want to restore credibility in the markets, we must follow the rules. The potential offenders are not able to do this. This is why we must strengthen the institutions of the European Union. I believe that we need to make that clear to the public and not the other way around. I would like to thank you for this.

My second point is that the Councils of Ministers are handing over more and more responsibility to the European Council when the situation gets difficult. Now there is a proposal to introduce a European Council of the 17. We have been fighting for 25 years in the European Union for majority voting in the Council of Ministers and now we are reintroducing the unanimity rule via the European Council. The European Council and the intergovernmental method not only involve a lack of democracy and transparency, but also inefficiency. We must also make this clear to the public and I would like to thank you for this.

intervention.name: Vytautas LANDSBERGIS
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Mr President, let me recall one of the ideas that our colleague Mr Zahradil has just expressed about the EU just turning into a debt Union. The debt of one becomes the debt of all. We may indeed consider that case, as debt will be covered by all without priority, without final consequences for a debtor.

It reminds me and some of us here as being analogous with the Soviet kolkhoz system, which was exactly the same or very similar: that of total irresponsibility by inefficient or corrupted kolkhoz management throughout the whole agriculture sector, because all wrongdoing or mistakes by individual managers and the political leadership were regularly covered by the state in the name of doctrine and a special sense of solidarity with an inefficient Soviet socialism.

a.text: (The President cut off the speaker)

intervention.name: Zita GURMAI
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Mr President, European integration was born as a means of overcoming divisions and providing a framework for achieving economic prosperity and sustaining – even reinforcing – Europe’s role in the world. We have, since then, created impressive political and institutional structures and are dealing with many different policies in the framework of the European Union.

However, our achievements are now being challenged as we face major internal and external challenges. The euro crisis represents our greatest test so far. No matter how hard all of us have worked for democratic governance, the legitimacy of the European construction is being questioned. This puts a strain on Europe’s solidarity, something that has only made us stronger in the long run. This was our standing point and should continue to be our beacon, even during the crisis.

I would like to thank President Barroso for addressing us today and draw his attention to an important point. All things considered, we are working for the people – all European citizens. No matter how clever the economic solutions we propose, we need a good foundation. We have to respect a principle which ensures that not a single person is left behind.

intervention.name: Sophia in 't VELD
intervention.p: Mr President, President Barroso is a bit distracted; I would like to say you spoke beautifully, I would like to congratulate you on your speech, President Barroso, but we are not going to talk our way out of this crisis. You rightly pointed out that we have most of all a political crisis. But here I would like to echo the words of my colleague, Sylvie Goulard, because for the last seven years you held the most powerful position in the European Union and much of this crisis, including the political crisis, came about on your watch.

So, Mr Barroso, the European Parliament and my group in particular have made many concrete proposals today to get out of the crisis. Parliament gave you its confidence in 2004 and 2009 but confidence is not a blank cheque. It has to be earned again and again. Mr Barroso, why should we have confidence this time that you will deliver and that you deserve our confidence in the next two years?

intervention.name: Petru Constantin LUHAN
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Mr President, a number of concerns have been expressed here today about the future of the European Union. However, we have also had an upbeat speech from the executive about not only exiting the crisis, but also about the European Union’s future. Unfortunately, the measures implemented by some European Union governments have proven to be ineffective. This is why now more than ever we need complete mobilisation to revive the European Union’s economy.

In this respect, I think that the European Union needs to take action as an entity and acquire the skills for coordinating fiscal policies at EU level and, if applicable, implement common economic governance, but with a well-funded budget. We must be able to respond promptly to needs at EU level and implement as quickly as possible appropriate provisions for managing crisis situations.

a.text: (The President cut off the speaker)

intervention.name: Nikolaos SALAVRAKOS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: Mr President, Mr Barroso, I applaud the belief that you have expressed in the future of Europe. If nothing else, I would like to congratulate you for trying. I am aware of the problems that you face. You are not alone, but you are trying. I shall say no more.

However, I fear that we started monetary union off on the wrong foot. How can we have a single currency with seventeen different governments, seventeen different decision-making centres and seventeen different centres buying bonds, all with different policies? Thus, in my opinion, we urgently need to speed up action on the economic union of Europe. Without economic union in Europe, I fear that our efforts will be in vain. There is something else I wish to say to you: as a lawyer, I know that public limited companies capitalise their capital gains. We have registered capital gains against the dollar. Please capitalise them.

intervention.name: José Manuel Barroso
intervention.role: President of the Commission
intervention.p: Mr President, first of all, let me start by thanking this House for the strong support given to my statement on behalf of the European Commission. I think it is very important for all of us in the European Commission to feel that support coming from the most important political forces in Europe and for you, who have been directly elected by our European citizens.

Of course I was not expecting unanimity. One Member of Parliament, a British nationalist, attacked me on the fact that I am not elected. I want to tell you that since the age of 29 I have always been elected by my own Parliament. I was Prime Minister of my country, I was leader of the opposition of my country and I am here, as President of the Commission, because this Parliament voted for me to be President of the European Commission.

If you do not respect the institution to which you belong yourself, this is not my problem. Regarding Britain, I would like to make this point to you. As far as I know, you have tried several times to be elected to your own British Parliament. How wise the British people are that they have never elected you to your own Parliament and sent you here.

If you want your country to leave the European Union, say it in London and try to get your country to agree. But do not say it here because, as far as we know, your institutions and your country want to remain in the European Union. If your country does not want to be in the European Union, do not speak on behalf of the others, do not speak on behalf of Poland, that just today set their commitment to the Community approach and to a stronger and ever-closer European Union. If Britain believes that it can, because of its past empire, or because of its dimension, defend its interests in the world alone, try to get that point across in your country. But I think the majority here believes, as was said, that to protect our interests, to defend our values in the world of globalisation, to speak with one voice with our American friends or China and Russia, we need a stronger European Union. This stronger European Union is also a way to reinforce our countries, the countries that we all represent around this House.

This point is very important. This is a point of substance, apart from the other funnier parts. How we build a European Union is a point of substance. Are we going to build a European Union against each other or with each other? That is why I welcome this message of support, not only from the most important political forces here and the consensus expressed, but also from the current Presidency of the Council, Poland. We need a Community that matters: a Community spirit and a Community approach to reinforce our common interests. We need to build a European Union with our Member States, but we also need to build a European Union based on the rassemblement of all the major pro-Europeans, the most important political forces of Europe.

I agree with Andrew Duff that we also probably need to reform some of our European political parties, so that we can also have a collective expression in the European public space of this European democracy. Today some of you said ‘yes, but’. Please, among pro-Europeans, do not say the ‘but’, just say ‘yes’. You do not say to your loved ones – your wife or your girlfriend, your husband or your boyfriend – ‘I love you, but’, you say ‘I love you, I support you’. We need your support to make Europe stronger because Europe’s real problem is, as I said, also a problem of confidence.

Let us be completely clear. The problems we have in Europe today did not arise because of the European institutions. The problems we have in Europe today arise because of narrow national interests that have prevented the European project from moving forward. So I say to those of you that criticise me, or the Commission, that we are ready to accept all your criticisms, but the Commission is proud of the work it has achieved. Today we have not only made a speech, but we have put forward a programme with proposals.

Everything I said last year in the European Sate of the Union I checked; we have delivered. Every proposal I made today to you, we will deliver and we need your support and not your doubts and your scepticism. That is very important today because we need to build this stronger support for a stronger Europe in a spirit of confidence. Today you are going to vote on the ‘six pack’; some of you do not agree but the proposals were made by the European Commission one year ago.

We have tabled 29 proposals for the Financial Regulation. Some of the points you have made are already on the table for the Council. About capital of banks we have put forward a capital requirements directive. Some of you do not agree but it is there, our proposal. About tax evasion we have asked the Council, and so far we have not yet received a mandate to negotiate with third countries the issues of taxation because what is happening so far is that countries are negotiating alone.

We have put forward the tax savings directive. Regarding the services publiques , the public services, I have committed to present it before the end of the year and we will do it. We are going to respect all our commitments and today I also put forward before you the financial transaction tax. So there is no lack of proposals. The question today is to get the support, not only of Parliament but also of our Member States. So when we speak about Europe we have to be clear about what we mean by Europe.

Because this is one of the problems in terms of the scepticism in Europe. Some people say Europe does not deliver. Let us put it frankly: is it Europe that does not deliver or some governments that do not deliver? This is the real question in terms of the European Union.

As I said, one of the problems is political and political confidence and we need to make the case for Europe. Today when some governments say: ‘we do not have enough support for the euro; we do not have some support for the European Union’, probably they are right. But we have to ask them: did you make the case for Europe? Did you make the case for the euro? Did you explain to your citizens what we have to lose if we do not keep our strong commitment to our common achievements? So we need to make the case for Europe. And this is a collective task from the European Commission, of course, from Parliament – and you have been elected and you can of course discuss this matter and I know you are doing it with your electors but also from our governments.

We need to make the case for a stronger Europe, that is why I have highlighted the importance of the political leadership, the political responsibility, and I believe that we can unite ourselves in terms of the points I have made.

The reality is, honourable Members, we have different sensibilities around Europe. We have those who like to highlight stability; others prefer to speak about growth. Those who prefer to insist on responsibility and discipline, others want to insist on solidarity and cohesion. We need all these ideas. We need to put together this vision of a common Europe and the points I have made today to you – and once again I want to thank you for all your support – are not only the points of a speech: they are the points of a commitment programme, and so let us work together to make it happen.

Let us work together to make Europe stronger, let us work together in a true community spirit with the respect for Community matters to deliver for our citizens a stronger, united and open Europe. I believe this is what we need in Europe and what the world needs from us.

intervention.name: Jerzy BUZEK
intervention.p: Thank you very much, Mr Barroso, for your presentation of the state of the Union, for the debate, for all that you have said and all the answers you have given. We are sure that this debate, held in the European Parliament every September, is of fundamental importance for shaping the future of the European Union.
With that we close this item and proceed to the vote.

intervention.name: Ilda FIGUEIREDO
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left - Vice
intervention.p: Mr President, this week has been the third debate in which I have participated: having been here from the start, I put my name down for the ‘catch-the-eye’ procedure in all three debates, but I have not been given the floor in any of them. I should like to know why I have been refused the floor in the ‘catch-the-eye’ procedure. Could it be because they knew I would take a different position; that I would talk about the protests in Portugal, the Portuguese workers and next Saturday’s demonstrations in Porto and Lisbon?
I should like an answer to this question, and I hereby express the protest of the Portuguese people against these policies.

intervention.name: Jerzy BUZEK
intervention.p: Ms Figueiredo, I had 56 colleagues’ names on the list, so 10 of you could not take the floor. You were one of the 10, that is all. I do not have any other explanation. We did not have enough time. I am very sorry about that.
Written statements (Rule 149)

intervention.name: Luís Paulo ALVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: The crisis we are experiencing requires swift and courageous responses. As the situation in Greece demonstrates, there is a need for an alternative agenda to extreme austerity, and for protection of the weakest and the unemployed, who have nothing to do with the cause of this crisis. As such, in addition to the necessary budgetary consolidation, Europe needs to ensure its ability to invest for growth, to create services and to maintain essential public services. The economic governance package should include a growth pact, in order that the Member States might make productive investments, capable of reversing the current economic situation. Moreover, Europe is not demonstrating long- and medium-term vision, and is exhausting itself with an austere reaction to the present crisis. Budgetary targets should exist in parallel with the Europe 2020 strategy targets. Decision-making processes should be made more democratic and robust, without nationalism, so that Europe can respond faster and more effectively. Europe also needs a system of Eurobonds to help stabilise the markets, a financial transactions tax to obtain new income and limit types of speculation, a stronger European budget equipped with own resources, and an end to tax havens.

intervention.name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: We cannot argue with your statement, President of the Commission, that the European Union must be reformed. The continuing and deepening crisis demonstrates very clearly that the existing model of EU governance is unable to react to complex situations and mobilise the political will to adopt decisions that may be radical but which are unavoidable. The only way for us to remain a Union of solidarity and unity is to review in principle the entire EU governance model. The Commission must become the body that draws up common guidelines on economic governance and has all the powers to monitor the economies of the Member States. Without a clear economic governance structure, the economic governance and coordination measures proposed will not lead to greater economic integration and the coordination of Member State economies or the monitoring of financial markets.

intervention.name: Ivo BELET
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: With this package of radical measures (the ‘six pack’), we are laying the groundwork for a strong European economic policy and creating a defence against potential financial crises in the future. We are laying the foundations for a healthy and strong single currency. These are the measures that will enable us and Europe to emerge stronger from the crisis. It is essential that the European Commission is put in the driving seat here, because that will enable it to ensure that governments respect these measures without fail and that Member States which go off the road are taken to task. On the basis of these clear rules, we now need to take further steps in order to kick the European economy into a higher gear. Eurobonds and project bonds, which President Barroso has announced here today, could play a vital role in this respect. Introduction of a financial transaction tax (FTT) is another important step forward. Europe is taking the lead with this and creating a very important instrument (EUR 55 billion of revenue per year) in order to bolster the economy and promote jobs. At the same time, the introduction of a FTT would send out a strong political signal to European citizens. With the FTT, Europe will be making it clear that financial institutions must themselves make a substantial contribution in times of severe financial and economic turmoil.

intervention.name: John BUFTON
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: The State of the Union address failed to acknowledge the disastrous year had by the EU and suggests forging ahead with deeper integration to prevent threats to key legislation such as the Schengen acquis and single currency. There are reasons why these have come under attack. They are unworkable and opposed by many within the EU. To adhere to them demonstrates how dismissive of public opinion and devoid of reason the Commission is. Regulating the financial market to resolve the outcomes of poor judgment by the Commission over the eurozone is thieving from the success of the City of London to feed the failures of the single currency. The naïve utopian view of the Commission is little more than a foolhardy path to failure. Such is the case with common migration policy. How can the Commission control and balance migration without impeding the liberty and mobility they claim are central tenets of the European vision? Expansion is laughable when the EU struggles to effectively operate in the extant Member States. Inking new FTAs undermines national variance and independence. Member States are being lead into a quagmire of interdependence where sovereignty will be an unattainable memory.

intervention.name: João FERREIRA
intervention.p: The speech made in the European Parliament today by the President of the European Commission was just another number for the markets to see. At the same time, it was an attempt to silence the critics who had been accusing the Commission and its President of inaction and of systematic submission to the German directorate of Chancellor Merkel. In the end, the applause that united the Group of the European People’s Party (Christian Democrats) and the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament is enlightening and symbolic of a ‘unity’ that has driven the EU and its Member States to the current crisis, which is still there, as can be seen from the adoption of the economic governance package, welcomed by Dr Barroso. That package represents the reinforcement of the Stability and Growth Pact and the restrictions inherent to it, which particularly affect the weaker economies and are largely responsible for Portugal’s weak economic growth over the last decade. As for the rest, strengthening the European Financial Stability Facility represents nothing more than transferring yet more public debt held by banks to the public sector; that is, onto the backs of the workers and the people. The financial transaction tax has been announced for the umpteenth time; doubts remain about its practical effects. For the time being, the most speculative products – such as derivatives – have been saved, with derisory taxes, whilst tax havens remain untouchable. Combating speculation has, therefore, had scant practical results.

intervention.name: Ilda FIGUEIREDO
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left - Vice
intervention.p: In the face of the most serious crisis of recent decades, to which the neoliberal policies of the European Union have contributed, the Commission is insisting on deepening capitalist and neoliberal integration, adorned with a few fig leaves of demagoguery that have not even tweaked the fundamentals of the powerful financial sector.

It is not enough to say that a financial transaction tax is being created, at a ridiculous rate, if tax havens continue to flourish and the derivatives markets continue to feed speculation on the sovereign debt of the countries with the most fragile economies.

Even the measure of increasing the rate of co-financing for countries with so-called financial assistance programmes, which we have been demanding for years, is too late and, unfortunately, does not even mean the Union budget is being increased.

By insisting on the same neoliberal and so-called austerity policies, on reinforcing the Stability and Growth Pact, and on the centralisation of economic and political power, what we will have is the deepening of economic asymmetries and social inequalities, and of unemployment and poverty, with no future prospects for the almost 23% of young people who are jobless or the more than 100 million people at risk of poverty.

That is why we support the struggle of the workers and the people for the break and change that is needed, as we will have in Portugal next Saturday with the demonstrations by the General Confederation of Portuguese Workers (CGTP).

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: In recent times we have been subjected to a deluge of catastrophic reports about the situation in the Eurozone, the EU and European integration as a whole. That the situation is critical I agree. On the other hand, a bit of historical perspective would not be out of place. The EU is still a successful project, which during its short time in existence has succeeded in uniting European nations and become a leading world force. Even if individual steps taken in its history can be criticised, I personally see the EU project so far as a huge success for multilateralism and international cooperation. At the same time I should like to add that I have my doubts on some of the scenarios that are presented here on a daily basis regarding the situation in the eurozone. I am particularly ashamed by the fact that at this very moment it is the Slovak government that is putting the brakes on measures to prevent the crisis from breaking out in its imminent next stage. That is why I would like to appeal to absolutely everyone involved in today’s debate to put aside their party colours and national interests, stop their short-term political point-scoring, and treat the EU as a single entity in the context of its history. The EU is still in good working order, even if the outlook is unclear. It all depends on our resolve, and I believe firmly that when the state of the Union is evaluated in the near future, we will not have to find that it has deteriorated or completely disintegrated. Let us avoid making a historical mistake.

intervention.name: Jiří HAVEL
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Mr President, I was honoured to listen to your report, and I would like to take this opportunity to thank the entire Commission for the work performed under your leadership. You are doing a difficult job in challenging times. At the same time, however, I have to admit that your report, in addition to the positive feelings, filled me with considerable unease. Regarding the future of the Union, you spoke of the need for further integration.
